History of Present Illness:
The patient is a 65 year old right handed man who initially
presented with a generalized convulsive seizure while driving. A
second episode occurred upon arrival to the ED. He has
subsequently been found to have a right frontal white matter
brain lesion and retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy, most
concerning for malignancy. The patient and his wife deny him
ever having shown seizure activity including clonus or staring
spells. He reports being healthy and has not had constitutional
symptoms including fevers, rigors, night sweats, or weight loss.
He has had no recurrence of seizures and now feels well. We are
being consulted for consideration of a brain biopsy of the right
frontal lesion.

1.4-cm hyperdensity in the right frontal lobe with surrounding
vasogenic edema. This is a nonspecific imaging finding and the
differential diagnosis includes tumor, encephalitis or venous
